trans-unit.source: Service Fabric application model concepts for actors
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric application model concepts for actors

trans-unit.source: Actors use the Service Fabric application model to manage the application lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: Actors use the Service Fabric application model to manage the application lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: Every Actor type is mapped to a Service Fabric [Service type](service-fabric-application-model.md#describe-a-service).
trans-unit.target: Every Actor type is mapped to a Service Fabric [Service type](service-fabric-application-model.md#describe-a-service).

trans-unit.source: Scalability for actor services
trans-unit.target: Scalability for actor services

trans-unit.source: Cluster administrators can create one or more actor services of each service type in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Cluster administrators can create one or more actor services of each service type in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Each of those actor services can have one or more partitions (similar to any other Service Fabric service).
trans-unit.target: Each of those actor services can have one or more partitions (similar to any other Service Fabric service).

trans-unit.source: The ability to create multiple services of a service type (which maps to an actor type) and the ability to create multiple partitions for a service allow the actor application to scale.
trans-unit.target: The ability to create multiple services of a service type (which maps to an actor type) and the ability to create multiple partitions for a service allow the actor application to scale.

trans-unit.source: Please see the article on [scalability](service-fabric-concepts-scalability.md) for more information.
trans-unit.target: Please see the article on [scalability](service-fabric-concepts-scalability.md) for more information.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Stateless actor services are required to have an [instance](service-fabric-availability-services.md#availability-of-service-fabric-stateless-services) count of 1.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Stateless actor services are required to have an [instance](service-fabric-availability-services.md#availability-of-service-fabric-stateless-services) count of 1.

trans-unit.source: Having more than one instance of a stateless actor service in a partition is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Having more than one instance of a stateless actor service in a partition is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, stateless actor services do not have the option of increasing instance count to achieve scalability.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, stateless actor services do not have the option of increasing instance count to achieve scalability.

trans-unit.source: They must use the scalability options that are described in the [scalability article](service-fabric-concepts-scalability.md).
trans-unit.target: They must use the scalability options that are described in the [scalability article](service-fabric-concepts-scalability.md).

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric partition concepts for stateless actors
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric partition concepts for stateless actors

trans-unit.source: Stateless actors are created within a partition of a Service Fabric stateless service.
trans-unit.target: Stateless actors are created within a partition of a Service Fabric stateless service.

trans-unit.source: The actor ID determines which partition the actor is created under.
trans-unit.target: The actor ID determines which partition the actor is created under.

trans-unit.source: The [instance](service-fabric-availability-services.md#availability-of-service-fabric-stateless-services) count for a stateless actor service must be 1.
trans-unit.target: The [instance](service-fabric-availability-services.md#availability-of-service-fabric-stateless-services) count for a stateless actor service must be 1.

trans-unit.source: Changing the instance count to any other value is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Changing the instance count to any other value is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Thus, the actor is created inside the single service instance within the partition.
trans-unit.target: Thus, the actor is created inside the single service instance within the partition.

trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] The Fabric Actors runtime emits some [events related to stateless actor instances](service-fabric-reliable-actors-diagnostics.md#events-related-to-stateless-actor-instances).

trans-unit.target: They are useful in diagnostics and performance monitoring.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric partition concepts for stateful actors
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric partition concepts for stateful actors

trans-unit.source: Stateful actors are created within a partition of the Service Fabric stateful service.
trans-unit.target: Stateful actors are created within a partition of the Service Fabric stateful service.

trans-unit.source: The actor ID determines which partition the actor is created under.
trans-unit.target: The actor ID determines which partition the actor is created under.

trans-unit.source: Each partition of the service can have one or more [replicas](service-fabric-availability-services.md#availability-of-service-fabric-stateful-services) that are placed on different nodes in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Each partition of the service can have one or more [replicas](service-fabric-availability-services.md#availability-of-service-fabric-stateful-services) that are placed on different nodes in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Having multiple replicas provides reliability for the actor state.
trans-unit.target: Having multiple replicas provides reliability for the actor state.

trans-unit.source: The resource manager optimizes the placement based on the available fault and upgrade domains in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The resource manager optimizes the placement based on the available fault and upgrade domains in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Two replicas of the same partition are never placed on the same node.
trans-unit.target: Two replicas of the same partition are never placed on the same node.

trans-unit.source: The actors are always created in the primary replica of the partition to which their actor ID maps to.
trans-unit.target: The actors are always created in the primary replica of the partition to which their actor ID maps to.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] The Fabric Actors runtime emits some [events related to stateful actor replicas](service-fabric-reliable-actors-diagnostics.md#events-related-to-stateful-actor-replicas).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] The Fabric Actors runtime emits some [events related to stateful actor replicas](service-fabric-reliable-actors-diagnostics.md#events-related-to-stateful-actor-replicas).

trans-unit.source: They are useful in diagnostics and performance monitoring.
trans-unit.target: They are useful in diagnostics and performance monitoring.

trans-unit.source: Recall that in the [VoiceMailBoxActor example presented earlier](#service-fabric-partition-concepts-for-actors), the actor with ID `-4952641569324299627` was created within partition `c146fe53-16d7-4d96-bac6-ef54613808ff`.
trans-unit.target: Recall that in the [VoiceMailBoxActor example presented earlier](#service-fabric-partition-concepts-for-actors), the actor with ID `-4952641569324299627` was created within partition `c146fe53-16d7-4d96-bac6-ef54613808ff`.

trans-unit.source: The EventSource event from that example also indicated that the actor was created in replica `130745418574851853` of that partition.
trans-unit.target: The EventSource event from that example also indicated that the actor was created in replica `130745418574851853` of that partition.

trans-unit.source: This was the primary replica of that partition at the time the actor was created.
trans-unit.target: This was the primary replica of that partition at the time the actor was created.

trans-unit.source: Actor state provider choices
trans-unit.target: Actor state provider choices

trans-unit.source: There are some default actor state providers that are included in the Actors runtime.
trans-unit.target: There are some default actor state providers that are included in the Actors runtime.

trans-unit.source: In order to choose an appropriate state provider for an actor service, it is necessary to understand how the state providers use the underlying Service Fabric platform features to make the actor state highly available.
trans-unit.target: In order to choose an appropriate state provider for an actor service, it is necessary to understand how the state providers use the underlying Service Fabric platform features to make the actor state highly available.

trans-unit.source: By default a stateful actor uses key value store actor state provider.
trans-unit.target: By default a stateful actor uses key value store actor state provider.

trans-unit.source: This state provider is built on the distributed Key-Value store provided by Service Fabric platform.
trans-unit.target: This state provider is built on the distributed Key-Value store provided by Service Fabric platform.

trans-unit.source: The state is durably saved on the local disk of the node hosting the primary [replica](service-fabric-availability-services.md#availability-of-service-fabric-stateful-services), as well as replicated and durably saved on the local disks of nodes hosting the secondary replicas.
trans-unit.target: The state is durably saved on the local disk of the node hosting the primary [replica](service-fabric-availability-services.md#availability-of-service-fabric-stateful-services), as well as replicated and durably saved on the local disks of nodes hosting the secondary replicas.

trans-unit.source: The state save is complete only when a quorum of replicas has committed the state to their local disks.
trans-unit.target: The state save is complete only when a quorum of replicas has committed the state to their local disks.

trans-unit.source: The Key-Value store has advanced capabilities to detect inconsistencies such as false progress and correct them automatically.
trans-unit.target: The Key-Value store has advanced capabilities to detect inconsistencies such as false progress and correct them automatically.

trans-unit.source: The Actors runtime also includes a `VolatileActorStateProvider`.
trans-unit.target: The Actors runtime also includes a `VolatileActorStateProvider`.

trans-unit.source: This state provider replicates the state to replicas but the state remains in-memory on the replica.
trans-unit.target: This state provider replicates the state to replicas but the state remains in-memory on the replica.

trans-unit.source: If one replica goes down and comes back up, its state is rebuilt from the other replica.
trans-unit.target: If one replica goes down and comes back up, its state is rebuilt from the other replica.

trans-unit.source: However if all of the replicas (copies of the state) go down simultaneously the state data will be lost.
trans-unit.target: However if all of the replicas (copies of the state) go down simultaneously the state data will be lost.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, this state provider is suitable for applications where the data can survive failures of few replicas and can survive the planned failovers such as upgrades.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, this state provider is suitable for applications where the data can survive failures of few replicas and can survive the planned failovers such as upgrades.

trans-unit.source: If all replicas (copies) are lost, then the data needs to be recreated using mechanisms external to Service Fabric.
trans-unit.target: If all replicas (copies) are lost, then the data needs to be recreated using mechanisms external to Service Fabric.

trans-unit.source: You can configure your stateful actor to use volatile actor state provider by adding the `VolatileActorStateProvider` attribute to the actor class or an assembly level attribute.
trans-unit.target: You can configure your stateful actor to use volatile actor state provider by adding the `VolatileActorStateProvider` attribute to the actor class or an assembly level attribute.
